RMPContact: Robert L. Howard DDNV Commanding Of
SafetyInspectionBy: EA Science, Engineering, Science and Technology

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at DDNV.
The Defense Distribution Norfolk, Virginia (DDNV), along with the host facility, the Naval Station Norfolk, Virginia, complies with extensive environmental, safety, and emergency response requirements. Emergency response procedures for the Fire Department follow the guidelines published by the U.S. Department of Transportation, North American Emergency Response Guidebook.  Policy for the Department is defined by NAVFAC Publication P1021, "Navy Shore Establishment Fire Protection/Prevention Program," OPNAV Instruction 11320.23 (establishes policy, standards, guidance and responsibilities for installation fire protection and emergency services), and OPNAV Instruction 5090.1 (establishes regional Naval On-Scene Commanders and Navy Facility Incident Commanders). 

These regulations were designed to meet the following objectives: 
                                         
1) To save lives.
2) To minimize and avoid injuries. 
3) To protect the environment.
4) To minimize property damage. 
  
The Emergency Response Procedures provides the reporting and notification procedures, evacuation procedures, and mitigation procedures that may be implemented to ensure operators respond effectively to an emergency situation. All emergency response employees are trained in their specific roles when responding to an emergency. 

A description of your facility and regulated substances handled.  
The DDNV provides standard packing operations, specialized storage operations, cold storage warehousing as well as hazardous material packing and shipment.  It also interfaces with direct vendor-to-customer and local delivery services including the packing and storage of new and repaired aircraft parts as well as the handling and shipping of radioactive and medical items.  The customer base includes more than 150 ships, from aircraft carriers to destroyers and submarines, which pull into Norfolk's piers for supplies.  The ma

jority of the workload comes from supplying the Navy's Atlantic and Mediterranean fleets, Atlantic bases and numerous shore establishments.  The DDNV also serves as the main supply point for a portion of the Navy that supports NATO as well as humanitarian relief efforts in the United States, the Caribbean, and other countries. The DDNV Refrigerated Warehouse in building CEP-156 is a cold storage facility located in the southwest portion of the Sewell's Point Area of the Naval Base Norfolk.  The facility is located directly south of Cold Storage Road, and access to the facility is provided through Second Street, which is south of Admiral Taussig Boulevard.  Building CEP-156 is a single-story building, approximately 231,800 square feet, used as a cold storage plant for all foods requiring chilling or freezing.  The building contains three cells - one chiller cell and one freezer cell constructed in 1975, and one freezer cell constructed in 1995.  CEP-156 uses ammonia to provide the refrigeration and this substance is the only regulated substance at the installation.


The release scenario.

The worst-case release scenario for ammonia models the EPA recommended parameters of a 10-minute release of all material in a single container to the air.  No passive mitigation is assumed.  This scenario assumes that the Control Pressure Receiver ruptures.  The alternative-release scenario for ammonia would involve failure of a flange or pipe on the high-pressure side of the system.  The pipe diameters for the Control Pressure Receiver, the Pilot Receiver, and the Auxilary Receiver are 1 ?" in diameter.  This would give a leak rate of 2,460 pounds per minute.  The DDNV ammonia refrigeration facility includes an extensive ammonia sensor bank, computer control for rapid shut-downs, and a 24 hour/day 7 day/week watchstander to monitor the process for operating parameters and for leak detection.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.

The ammonia Prevention Program will requires the greatest amount of resourcing.  This program mirrors an existing Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) regulation called "Process Safety Management" (PSM).  The ammonia located at building CEP-156 is already subject to the OSHA PSM requirements.  The Section 112(r) Prevention Program is a twelve-element matrix of requirements that, collectively, reduces the potential for having an accident.  The program requires that formal safety procedures be prepared and documented. Formal management of the prevention program and the facility is performed via the DDNV ammonia refrigeration contractor, currently Webb Technology, Inc.  Webb Technology, Inc.  specializes in ammonia facilities and provides technical and operational expertise.

Five-year accident history. 
Within the past five years, the ammonia refrigeration process has had no accidental release that caused offsite impacts provided in the risk management program.  

The emergency response program.  
In the event of fire, explosion, release of a regulated substance or other emergency, NSNV maintains 114 full time fire fighters with a minimum of 41 people per shift.  The Fire Department has 22 personnel that are HAZMAT-trained. The Naval Station Norfolk Fire Department is a comprehensive community and emergency response service system.  The Fire Department has a total of 114 fire fighters with a minimum of 42 people per shift (There are two shifts.). There are four segments of the Fire Department that are individually assigned responsibility for areas of the post.  Emergency response personnel participate in major regulations (such as the RM) with other directorates/divisions that require emergency service planning.  Emergency response procedures for the Fire Department follow the guidelines published by the U.S. Department of Transportation, North American Emergency Response Guidebook.  Policy for the Department is defined by NAVFAC Publication P1021, "N

avy Shore Establishment Fire Protection/Prevention Program," OPNAV Instruction 11320.23 (establishes policy, standards, guidance and responsibilities for installation fire protection and emergency services), and OPNAV Instruction 5090.1 (establishes regional Naval On-Scene Commanders and Navy Facility Incident Commanders). 

Planned changes to improve safety.  

The DDNV Risk Management committee is currently meeting to examine the process hazard analysis recommendations.  All recommendations will be examined and a schedule adopted for implementation.  The committee, established by the direction of the Commanding Officer of the DDNV, consists of representatives from all installations organizations that have a participatory interest in safety.
